item.title: Emacs
item.description: Basic configuration General commands Kill ring Calculator Console-size split screen MELPA package repository Solarized theme For R Emacs Speaks Statistics Auto-complete Smart underscores Poly-mode for R + Markdown Custom keyboard shortcuts Jumping to function definitions For writing Spell checking Thesaurus and synonyms Grammar checking For LaTeX Word count Chunk folding For Markdown Table formatting Markdown live preview For Python Elpy python mode Send commands to a specific buffer For C/CPP Tags For Shell For WDL workflows For file manipulation Compare two files (diff) CSV/TSV Dired mode For Version Control File encryption On HPCs For online notes Evernote Simplenote For OSX Maximize window at opening Keybindings Ispell Explicit path definition I use Emacs for almost everything: coding, writing, taking notes, managing tasks, using version control, preparing presentations.

item.title: Expression
item.description: Writing Grammarly lessons Synonyms General Starting the sentence Explanation Not sure Opening Nice expression/style Introduce the second part of a sentence Introduction/reviews Intro the intro Pionner work Changing subject More Closing Discussion Oral Expression Advices Writing Some recommendations from Sportscience: i.e. and e.g. only within parenthesis (is that a thing?) aim for economy. However or synonyms at most once per paragraph.

item.title: LaTeX
item.description: Cheatsheets Standard packages TinyTeX Misc Document class Page size Font sizes and style Change the symbol in lists Math calligraphy Languages and encoding Links Table of contents Metadata Figures Position Sub-figures Supplementary figures Tables Control tabular width Add vertical padding Supplementary tables Spanning columns/rows Align columns Rectangular selection/cut/paste Tables from R Code blocks For manuscripts Abstract Author affiliation Text formatting Notes/comments using the todo package Main text and supplements in two documents Compare versions and highlight revisions One figure = one file Bibliography Reduce long list of authors “Name Year” style Order of initials No URL or DOI Presentations Changing the font Section slides Themes Aspect ratio Background image Backup slides Link to frame A lot of good information in the LaTeX Wikibook.

item.title: Markdown
item.description: Markdown tips YAML header Bibliography Markdown to PDF report Custom document header Comments Custom tables Markdown to Word document Markdown to HTML pages Markdown to slides PDF slides HTML slides Websites blogdown websites Jekyll websites (deprecated) R Markdown I compile markdown documents using the RMarkdown R package (which uses Pandoc). Rscript -e 'rmarkdown::render("document.md")' The output format is either defined in the YAML header (see below), or can be specified with output_format=.

item.title: Math/Stats
item.description: Probability distributions Binomial Hypergeometric Normal Poisson Beta-binomial Beta Statistical tests Student t-test Fisher’s exact test \(\chi^2\) test Wilcoxon test ANOVA Regression & Machine Learning Linear regression LASSO LOESS Machine Learning basics CART Neural Networks SVM Misc stats Markov Model Monte Carlo methods MCMC Hidden Markov Model Maximum Likelihood Estimation Expectation-Maximization Greedy algorithm Bayesian vs Frequentist FM-index Graph theory De Bruijn graphs Hamiltonian path Euclidian path Algebra SVD decomposition PCA All of this is mostly extracted from Wikipedia.

item.title: Tools
item.description: Git Snakemake bcftools jq vd rsync Docker WDL Makefile FTP For file conversion Misc PDF Git Commit all modification and added files: git commit -am "informative message" To show all the history of a file: git log -p -- file To retrieve a specific version of a file: git show COMMIT:file Revert repo to a specific commit: git checkout COMMIT Undo a commit: git reset HEAD~ and then for the real commit git commit -c ORIG_HEAD.

item.title: About
item.description: About this website This is where I put all the useful information I keep on forgetting. Instead of googling the same things over and over, wasting time and server energy I put them here. It’s like a second memory, better than my hippocampus, my hippocamPLUS… About me Personal page with links. Twitter. My current lab Computational Genomics Lab at UCSC. Genomics Institute at UCSC My previous labs Bourque Lab.
